sen.j: 片山北海（かたやま ほっかい、享保8年1月10日 (旧暦)（1723年2月14日） - 寛政2年9月12日 (旧暦)（1790年10月19日））は、江戸時代中期の日本の儒者、漢詩人である。
sen.e: Hokkai KATAYAMA (February 14, 1723 - October 19, 1790) was a Confucian and a composer of Chinese poems in Japan who lived during the middle of the Edo period.
Hokkai KATAYAMA (February 14, 1723 - October 19, 1790) was a Confucian and a composer of Chinese poems in Japan who lived during the middle of the Edo period.
Hokkai KATAYAMA (February 14, 1723 - October 19, 1790) was a Confucian and a composer of Chinese poems in Japan who lived during the middle of the Edo period.

sen.j: 京都の江村北海、江戸の入江北海とともに三都の三北海と称された。
sen.e: Along with Hokkai EMURA of Kyoto and Hokkai IRIE of Edo, he was referred to as the three Hokkai of three cities (Kyoto, Edo, and Osaka).
Along with Hokkai EMURA of Kyoto and Hokkai IRIE of Edo, he was referred to as the three Hokkai of three cities (Kyoto, Edo, and Osaka).
Along with Hokkai EMURA of Kyoto and Hokkai IRIE of Edo, he was referred to as the three Hokkai of three cities (Kyoto, Edo, and Osaka).

sen.j: 名前を猷、字は孝秩、通称を忠蔵、号は北海の他に堂号でもある孤松館がある。
sen.e: His name was Yu, his azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was Kotetsu, his common name was Tadakura, and other than Hokkai as his go (pen name), he had Komatsukan which was also the name of his house.

His name was Yu, his azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was Kotetsu, his common name was Tadakura, and other than Hokkai as his go (pen name), he had Komatsukan which was also the name of his house.

His name was Yu, his azana (Chinese courtesy name which was, historically, the name formerly given to adult Chinese men, used in place of their given name in formal situations; scholars and the literati of Japan adopted this custom of courtesy name) was Kotetsu, his common name was Tadakura, and other than Hokkai as his go (pen name), he had Komatsukan which was also the name of his house.

sen.j: 大坂で混沌詩社などを興して、頼春水、尾藤二洲、古賀精里、木村蒹葭堂など多くの優れた門弟を輩出した。
sen.e: He started Konton-shisha (Chinese poetry club) in Osaka, and turned out many outstanding disciples such as Shunsui RAI, Jishu BIDO, Seiri KOGA, and Kenkado KIMURA.
sen.cmt: 名の読み方は、「和歌俳諧人名辞典」（日外アソシエーツ）を参考に致しました。
sen.e: He started Konton-shisha (Chinese poetry club) in Osaka, and turned out many outstanding disciples such as Shunsui RAI, Jishu BIDO, Seiri KOGA, and Kenkado KIMURA.
He started Konton-shisha (Chinese poetry club) in Osaka, and turned out many outstanding disciples such as Shunsui RAI, Jishu BIDO, Seiri KOGA, and Kenkado KIMURA.

sen.j: 北海は、越後国弥彦村（現 新潟県西蒲原郡弥彦村）の農家に生まれる。
sen.e: Hokkai was born to a farming household in Yahiko-mura, Echigo Province (the present Yahiko-mura, Nishikanbara-gun, Niigata Prefecture).
Hokkai was born to a farming household in Yahiko-mura, Echigo Province (the present Yahiko-mura, Nishikanbara-gun, Niigata Prefecture).
Hokkai was born to a farming household in Yahiko-mura, Echigo Province (the present Yahiko-mura, Nishikanbara-gun, Niigata Prefecture).

sen.j: 父は黙翁といい、母は三浦氏の出自。
sen.e: His father was called Mokuo, and his mother was from the Miura clan.
His father was called Mokuo, and his mother was from the Miura clan.
His father was called Mokuo, and his mother was from the Miura clan.

sen.j: この村が日本海に面していたことから長じた後に北海と号することになる。
sen.e: Since this village was facing the Japanese sea, he referred to himself as Hokkai as he grew older.
Since this village was facing the Japanese sea, he referred to himself as Hokkai as he grew older.
Since this village was facing the Japanese sea, he referred to himself as Hokkai as he grew older.

sen.j: 10歳になるまでに四書などの教えを受けるが、非凡な才能を示したため、周囲の大人はこの子に学問を仕込もうとした。
sen.e: Until the age of 10, he was taught the teachings of Shisho (The Four Books of Confucianism), but since he displayed remarkable talents, the adults around him tried to educate him.
Until the age of 10, he was taught the teachings of Shisho (The Four Books of Confucianism), but since he displayed remarkable talents, the adults around him tried to educate him.
Until the age of 10, he was taught the teachings of Shisho (The Four Books of Confucianism), but since he displayed remarkable talents, the adults around him tried to educate him.

sen.j: しかし辺縁の地にて師が見つからず、長岡市、新発田市、高田市などに遊学させるも相応しい師を見つけられずにいた。
sen.e: However, they could not find a teacher near the place they lived, and although they made him study in such places as Nagaoka City, Shibata City, and Takada City, they still could not find a suitable teacher.

However, they could not find a teacher near the place they lived, and although they made him study in such places as Nagaoka City, Shibata City, and Takada City, they still could not find a suitable teacher.

However, they could not find a teacher near the place they lived, and although they made him study in such places as Nagaoka City, Shibata City, and Takada City, they still could not find a suitable teacher.

sen.j: 18歳になると京都に出て、師を探し求めたが敬服に値する人物になかなか出会うことができずにいた。
sen.e: When he turned 18 years old, Hokkai went to Kyoto and looked for a teacher, but he was unable to meet a person whom he could admire.
When he turned 18 years old, Hokkai went to Kyoto and looked for a teacher, but he was unable to meet a person whom he could admire.
When he turned 18 years old, Hokkai went to Kyoto and looked for a teacher, but he was unable to meet a person whom he could admire.

sen.j: 北海が初心より志が高かったことが伺われる。
sen.e: One can gather that Hokkai had more ambition than his initial determination.
One can gather that Hokkai had more ambition than his initial determination.
One can gather that Hokkai had more ambition than his initial determination.

sen.j: 元文5年、ようやく意中の師 宇野明霞に出会い入門する。
sen.e: In 1740, he finally met a teacher named Asaka UNO, and became his disciple.
In 1740, he finally met a teacher named Asaka UNO, and became his disciple.
In 1740, he finally met a teacher named Asaka UNO, and became his disciple.

sen.j: 北海は師を敬い、その学説を慕った。
sen.e: Hokkai admired his teacher, and adored his theories.
Hokkai admired his teacher, and adored his theories.
Hokkai admired his teacher, and adored his theories.

sen.j: また師 明霞も北海の器を見抜き、信任が篤かった。
sen.e: Hokkai's teacher, Asaka also saw his caliber, and trusted him deeply.
Hokkai's teacher, Asaka also saw his caliber, and trusted him deeply.
Hokkai's teacher, Asaka also saw his caliber, and trusted him deeply.

sen.j: この師弟関係は6年続いたが、明霞が死去するに及んで起居する家を失うことになる。
sen.e: This teacher and student relationship continued for six years, but Hokkai became homeless when Asaka died.
This teacher and student relationship continued for six years, but Hokkai became homeless when Asaka died.
This teacher and student relationship continued for six years, but Hokkai became homeless when Asaka died.

sen.j: 加えて息子の出世を期待して身を寄せていた父親と貧困生活を強いられてしまう。
sen.e: In addition, he was forced to live in destitution with his father who had been living with him, hoping for his son's success.
In addition, he was forced to live in destitution with his father who had been living with him, hoping for his son's success.
In addition, he was forced to live in destitution with his father who had been living with him, hoping for his son's success.

sen.j: しかし、親孝行をしながら苦学して学問を続けた。
sen.e: However, Hokkai continued to study hard while being dutiful to his father.
However, Hokkai continued to study hard while being dutiful to his father.
However, Hokkai continued to study hard while being dutiful to his father.

sen.j: 明霞の門弟に大坂の富商の者がいて、北海と知己であったことで、大坂に招かれて開塾することとなった。
sen.e: There was a disciple of Asaka who was a wealthy merchant that lived in Osaka, and since he was an acquaintance of Hokkai, Hokkai was invited to Osaka in order to open a school.
There was a disciple of Asaka who was a wealthy merchant that lived in Osaka, and since he was an acquaintance of Hokkai, Hokkai was invited to Osaka in order to open a school.
There was a disciple of Asaka who was a wealthy merchant that lived in Osaka, and since he was an acquaintance of Hokkai, Hokkai was invited to Osaka in order to open a school.

sen.j: 北海は言葉少なく、優しい人柄で知られ、身分によって人を差別することがなかった。
sen.e: Hokkai was known for being taciturn and having a gentle personality, and did not discriminate according to one's social standing.
Hokkai was known for being taciturn and having a gentle personality, and did not discriminate according to one's social standing.
Hokkai was known for being taciturn and having a gentle personality, and did not discriminate according to one's social standing.

sen.j: また政治的な野心を持つことなく、しかも儒者として時宜にかなった実践的な学を説いた。
sen.e: Furthermore, he did not have political ambitions, and as a Confucian, he expounded doctrines that were timely and practical.
Furthermore, he did not have political ambitions, and as a Confucian, he expounded doctrines that were timely and practical.
Furthermore, he did not have political ambitions, and as a Confucian, he expounded doctrines that were timely and practical.

sen.j: 世間の評判はたちまち高まり、三十数年の間で延べ3000人以上の門弟がいたといわれる。
sen.e: His reputation was quickly heightened, and in some thirty years, he had more than about 3,000 disciples.
His reputation was quickly heightened, and in some thirty years, he had more than about 3,000 disciples.
His reputation was quickly heightened, and in some thirty years, he had more than about 3,000 disciples.

sen.j: 和泉国岸和田藩の岡部候など多くの諸侯が北海の評判を知り、藩儒として招聘するがすべて固辞している。
sen.e: On learning about Hokkai's reputation, there were many lords such as lord Okabe of Kishiwada Domain in Izumi Province who invited him as Hanju (a Confucian scholar who work for a domain), but Hokkai firmly declined them all.

On learning about Hokkai's reputation, there were many lords such as lord OKABE of Kishiwada Domain in Izumi Province who invited him as Hanju (a Confucian scholar who work for a domain), but Hokkai firmly declined them all.
sen.cmt: 岡部を大文字に変更しました。
sen.e: On learning about Hokkai's reputation, there were many lords such as lord OKABE of Kishiwada Domain in Izumi Province who invited him as Hanju (a Confucian scholar who work for a domain), but Hokkai firmly declined them all.

sen.j: 淀橋横町の居宅には一本の老松があったためここを孤松館と称した。
sen.e: Since there was an old pine tree that stood in his house in Yodobashi yokocho, he referred to the place as Komatsukan.
Since there was an old pine tree that stood in his house in Yodobashi yokocho, he referred to the place as Komatsukan.
Since there was an old pine tree that stood in his house in Yodobashi yokocho, he referred to the place as Komatsukan.

sen.j: 多くの文人墨客がここに集い、酒を飲みながら詩作に耽り、政治談義などをした。
sen.e: Many writers and artists gathered and composed poetry and poems while drinking and talking about politics.
Many writers and artists gathered and composed poetry and poems while drinking and talking about politics.
Many writers and artists gathered and composed poetry and poems while drinking and talking about politics.

sen.j: 北海は酒を嗜まなかったが、これにつきあい倦むことがなかったという。
sen.e: Hokkai did not drink, but went along with them and had not gotten tired of it.
Hokkai did not drink, but went along with them and had not gotten tired of it.
Hokkai did not drink, but went along with them and had not gotten tired of it.

sen.j: 若き日の尾藤二洲が服部南郭の詩について議論しようとしたが、北海はこれに応えず平然と煙草を吹かしていた。
sen.e: Jishu BIDO, when he was young, tried to argue against the poems that Nankaku HATTORI wrote, but Hokkai smoked tobacco with composure and did not respond.
Jishu BIDO, when he was young, tried to argue against the poems that Nankaku HATTORI wrote, but Hokkai smoked tobacco with composure and did not respond.
Jishu BIDO, when he was young, tried to argue against the poems that Nankaku HATTORI wrote, but Hokkai smoked tobacco with composure and did not respond.

sen.j: 面倒な文学論などせず自由で気楽な雰囲気が伝わってくる逸話である。
sen.e: This is an anecdote that tells of a free and light hearted atmosphere without the serious treatise on literature.
This is an anecdote that tells of a free and light hearted atmosphere without the serious treatise on literature.
This is an anecdote that tells of a free and light hearted atmosphere without the serious treatise on literature.

sen.j: また横笛の名手でもあり、煎茶道を嗜む風流人でもあった。
sen.e: He was also a master of Oteki (transverse flute) as well as a man of refined taste who was fond of green tea ceremony.
He was also a master of Oteki (transverse flute) as well as a man of refined taste who was fond of green tea ceremony.
He was also a master of Oteki (transverse flute) as well as a man of refined taste who was fond of green tea ceremony.

sen.j: 明和元年（1764年）、混沌詩社が創立され北海はその盟主に推されるが、たちまち大坂で最も盛んな詩社となった。
sen.e: Konton-shisha was established in 1764, and Hokkai was recommended as the leader, and it quickly became the most active poetry club in Osaka.
Konton-shisha was established in 1764, and Hokkai was recommended as the leader, and it quickly became the most active poetry club in Osaka.
Konton-shisha was established in 1764, and Hokkai was recommended as the leader, and it quickly became the most active poetry club in Osaka.

sen.j: 宇野明霞の同門で生涯にわたる親友に、相国寺 禅僧大典顕常がいる。
sen.e: His life time friend, Daiten KENJO, was his fellow pupil of Asaka UNO, and a Zen monk of Shokoku-ji Temple,.
His life time friend, Daiten KENJO, was his fellow pupil of Asaka UNO, and a Zen monk of Shokoku-ji Temple,.
His life time friend, Daiten KENJO, was his fellow pupil of Asaka UNO, and a Zen monk of Shokoku-ji Temple,.

sen.j: 享年68。
sen.e: He died at the age of 68.
He died at the age of 68.
He died at the age of 68.

sen.j: 梅松院（大阪市天王寺区城南寺町）に眠る。
sen.e: He is buried in Baishoin (Jonantera machi, Tennoji Ward, Osaka City).
He is buried in Baishoin (Jonantera machi, Tennoji Ward, Osaka City).
He is buried in Baishoin (Jonantera machi, Tennoji Ward, Osaka City).

sen.j: 北海は生涯、著作を著すことを好まず、生前刊行されるものはなかったが、没後に門人によってその詩編が編集され出版されている。
sen.e: All through his life, Hokkai did not take a liking to writing his own book, and there were none that became published when he was alive; but book of his songs were complied and published by his disciples after his death.

All through his life, Hokkai did not take a liking to writing his own book, and there were none that became published when he was alive; but book of his songs were complied and published by his disciples after his death.

All through his life, Hokkai did not take a liking to writing his own book, and there were none that became published when he was alive; but book of his songs were complied and published by his disciples after his death.

sen.j: 『北海文集』
sen.e: "Hokkai bunshu" (Hokkai anthology in 12 volumes)
"Hokkai bunshu" (Hokkai anthology in 12 volumes)

sen.j: 『北海詩集』
sen.e: "Hokkai shishu" (Collected poems of Hokkai in seven volumes)

sen.j: 『混沌社詩稿』
sen.e: "Kontonsha shiko" (Manuscripts of poems by Kontonsha in three volumes)
sen.cmt: 「混沌詩社会稿」も、見受けられました（日本漢文学大辞典）
